title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
Bar chart

ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(x=RACE))+
  geom_bar()





Horizontal bar chart
Use coordinate to change bar into horizontal

ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(x=RACE))+
  geom_bar()+
  coord_flip()+
  theme_minimal()

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
Histogram

hist(exam_data$MATHS)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
Density plot
it is a good way to replace histogram for continuous data if its distribution is smooth

ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=MATHS,colour=GENDER))+

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
Dotplot

ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=MATHS))+
  geom_dotplot(dotsize=0.5,binwidth = 3)+
  scale_y_continuous(NULL,breaks = NULL) #remove y-axis value

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
Boxplot and Notch
Notch(缺口) can check by whether notches are overlapping to see whether medians are the same

ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=GENDER,y=MATHS))+
  geom_boxplot(notch=TRUE)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
Violin Plot
Can compare more clearly about the difference of distributions of multiple data

ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=GENDER,y=MATHS))+

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
Scatter plot

ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=ENGLISH,y=MATHS))+
  geom_point()+
  geom_smooth()+
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),ylim=c(0,100))

`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'






Combine scatter and boxplot

ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=GENDER,y=MATHS))+
  geom_point(position="jitter",size=0.2)+
  geom_boxplot()






Statistical summary
Add statistical summary can use stat_summary or overwrite by a new geom_ setting

ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=GENDER,y=MATHS))+
  geom_point(position='jitter')+
  geom_boxplot()+
  stat_summary(geom="point",fun='mean',color='red',size=4)





ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=GENDER,y=MATHS))+
  geom_boxplot()+
  geom_point(stat="summary",        
             colour ="red",          
             size=4)

No summary function supplied, defaulting to `mean_se()`

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
Create 2D panel

ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=MATHS))+

ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=MATHS))+

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
exam_data <- read.csv("data/Exam_data.csv")


ggrepel
An extension of ggplot that can deal with overlapping text For example, add “_repel” to geom_label

ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=MATHS,y=ENGLISH))+
  geom_point()+
  geom_smooth(method=lm,linewidth=0.5)+
  geom_label_repel(aes(label=ID),fontface='bold')+ 
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),ylim=c(0,100))+ 
  ggtitle('English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3"')

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'


Warning: ggrepel: 317 unlabeled data points (too many overlaps). Consider
increasing max.overlaps







ggplot theme

p1 <- ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=MATHS))+
  geom_histogram(bins=20,
                 boundary=100,
                 color='grey25',
                 fill='grey90')+
  theme_gray()+
  ggtitle("Distribution of math scores")
p1





ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=MATHS))+
  geom_histogram(bins=20,
                 boundary=100,
                 color='grey25',
                 fill='grey90')+
  theme_economist()+
  ggtitle("Distribution of math scores")






Working with hrbthems package
More fonts and label placements choices, adjust by axis_title size, base_size, axis_text_size

ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=MATHS))+
  geom_histogram(bins=20,boundary=100,
                 fill='grey25',
                 color='grey90')+
  ggtitle("Distribution of math scores")+
  theme_ipsum(axis_title_size = 20,base_size=20,grid='Y') 






Beyond Single Graph

p2 <- ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=ENGLISH))+
  geom_histogram(bins=20, boundary=100,fill='grey20',color='grey90')+
  ggtitle("Distribution of English score")+
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100))
p2





p3 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x= MATHS, 
                 y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")
p3

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'






Combining two ggplot2 graphs

p1|p2




“|” operator to stack two ggplot2 graphs,
“/” operator to place the plots beside each other,
“()” operator the define the sequence of the plotting


Add tag

((p1 / p2) | p3) + 
  plot_annotation(tag_levels = 'I')

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'







Place plots on top of below other plots

p3 + inset_element(p2, 
                   left = 0.02, 
                   bottom = 0.7, 
                   right = 0.5, 
                   top = 1)

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'







Use patchwork and ggtheme

patchwork <- p3| (p1 / p2)
patchwork & theme_economist()+theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 9))

`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: In Class Exercise 1
text:
Horizontal bar chart

ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(x=RACE))+
  geom_bar()+
  coord_flip()+
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(
    panel.background = element_rect(fill='lightblue',color = 'lightblue'),
    panel.grid.major = element_line(colour = 'white',size = 0.5,linewidth =  'solid'),
    panel.grid.minor = element_line(colour = 'white',size=0.25,linewidth = 'solid')
  )

Warning: The `size` argument of `element_line()` is deprecated as of ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use the `linewidth` argument instead.






Bar chart with label

Bar chart with label 1. function(x) counts the occurrence frequency of different x and minor constant length(x), allowing x axis to sort by the count value by descending order.
state=“count” indicate will use count method and applies to ..count.. and the plot
aes() to map with variables in the plot. paste0 is to concatenate strings
“after_stat(count)” or “..count..”(new version) means count of observations in each category
vjust is the lable position, -1 means a little above from the bar.
use theme(axis.title.y to adjust y axis title angle)


ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(x=reorder(RACE,RACE,function(x)-length(x))))+
  geom_bar()+
  ylim(0,220)+
  xlab("RACE")+
  ylab("No. of \nPupils")+
  geom_text(stat ="count",aes(label=paste0(after_stat(count),",",                                       round(after_stat(count)/sum(after_stat(count))*100,1),"%")),
            vjust=-1)+
  theme(axis.title.y=element_text(angle=0))






Use fct_infreq() of forcats package

Use Command + Shift + M to type %>%
fct_infreq can count the occurrence frequency of each category, and reorder by descending order
Mutate create a new column, and use %>% to modify and apply new changes to the data frame.


exam_data %>% 
  mutate(RACE=fct_infreq(RACE)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(RACE))+
  geom_bar()+
  ylim(0,220)+
  xlab("RACE")+
  ylab("No. of \nPupils")+
  geom_text(stat ="count",aes(label=paste0(after_stat(count),",",                                       round(after_stat(count)/sum(after_stat(count))*100,1),"%")),
            vjust=-1)+
  theme(axis.title.y=element_text(angle=0))

title: In Class Exercise 1
text:
Histogram

Add mean and median line

Use vline to draw vertical line.
xintercept as x-axis variable of MATHS
na.rm=T(True), means apply method of removing missing values before caculating mean.


ggplot(data=exam_data,aes(MATHS))+
  geom_histogram(bins=20,boundary=100,fill='lightblue',color='black')+
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept=mean(MATHS,na.rm=T)),color='red',
             linetype='dashed',size=1)+
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept=median(MATHS,na.rm=TRUE)),color='grey',linetype='dashed',
             size=1)

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
ℹ Please use `linewidth` instead.







Color comparison and facet grid

guides(fill=FALSE) means to turn off legend
create new histogram, one use sub_data without gender column, one use data and with black line and fill different color by gender.


data <- exam_data
sub_data <- data[,-3]

ggplot(data,aes(x=ENGLISH,fill=GENDER))+
  geom_histogram(data=sub_data,fill='grey',alpha=0.5)+
  geom_histogram(colour='black')+
  facet_wrap(~GENDER)+
  guides(fill=FALSE)+
  theme_bw()

Warning: The `<scale>` argument of `guides()` cannot be `FALSE`. Use "none" instead as
of ggplot2 3.3.4.
